articles.headline: Suburban G.O.P. Voters Sour on Party, Raising Republican Fears for 2018
articles.snippet: A narrower-than-expected victory in Kansas and an even tougher contest next week in Georgia are highlighting Republicans’ troubles with affluent white voters.
articles.abstract: A narrower-than-expected victory in Kansas and an even tougher contest next week in Georgia are highlighting Republicans’ troubles with affluent white voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALPHARETTA, Ga. — A gray mood has settled over conservative-leaning voters in some of the country’s most reliably Republican congressional districts, as the party’s stumbles in Washington demoralize them and leave lawmakers scrambling to energize would-be supporters in a series of off-year elections.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Turkey in Turmoil and Chaos Since Purge Aimed at Dissenters
articles.snippet: The government has fired or suspended about 130,000 people suspected of being dissidents from the public and private sectors since a coup attempt last summer.
articles.abstract: The government has fired or suspended about 130,000 people suspected of being dissidents from the public and private sectors since a coup attempt last summer.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — When Aynur Barkin became one of roughly 40,000 teachers purged from Turkey’s education system after last year’s attempted coup against President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, she was not immediately replaced. As a result, her second-grade students were forced to join the third grade, tripling their original class size.

articles.headline: After Campaign Exit, Manafort Borrowed From Businesses With Trump Ties
articles.snippet: A shell company created by Paul Manafort the same day he left the presidential campaign quickly received $13 million in loans from the businesses.
articles.abstract: A shell company created by Paul Manafort the same day he left the presidential campaign quickly received $13 million in loans from the businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Aug. 19 was an eventful day for Paul Manafort.

articles.headline: Trump Reversals Hint at Wall Street Wing’s Sway in White House
articles.snippet: Startling shifts on China and the Export-Import Bank and the possible reappointment of the chairwoman of the Federal Reserve show financiers may be gaining the upper hand over the populists.
articles.abstract: Startling shifts on China and the Export-Import Bank and the possible reappointment of the chairwoman of the Federal Reserve show financiers may be gaining the upper hand over the populists.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump made three startling economic policy reversals on Wednesday, stepping away from pledges he made as a candidate and even policies he supported only days ago.

articles.headline: Why ‘Sorry’ Is Still the Hardest Word
articles.snippet: The representatives of United Airlines and the White House both found themselves grappling with the increasingly common ritual: the public apology.
articles.abstract: The representatives of United Airlines and the White House both found themselves grappling with the increasingly common ritual: the public apology.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I’m sorry.” Two simple words, not so simply said.

articles.headline: The Murdochs Assess the O’Reilly Damage
articles.snippet: Bill O’Reilly has left Fox News for a vacation while his employers decide whether they should force him from the network over sexual harassment accusations.
articles.abstract: Bill O’Reilly has left Fox News for a vacation while his employers decide whether they should force him from the network over sexual harassment accusations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bill O’Reilly left Fox News this week for a long-planned vacation to Italy and the Vatican, with his fate in the hands of a Murdoch family calculating the risks and rewards of keeping him on or forcing him out of the network.
articles.byline: By Emily Steel and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Trump Plan Would Curtail Protections for Detained Immigrants
articles.snippet: As the administration tries to find jail space for its crackdown on illegal immigration, it is moving to curtail rules regarding the health and safety of detainees.
articles.abstract: As the administration tries to find jail space for its crackdown on illegal immigration, it is moving to curtail rules regarding the health and safety of detainees.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than 15 years, jails that hold immigrants facing deportation have had to follow a growing list of requirements:
